name: Evil Genius
description: Everybody wants to rule the world! Achieve global power with EVIL GENIUS, the one and only complete world domination simulator. All the everyday tasks of the deliciously wicked mastermind are available to experience and master from building your ultra-secret base to developing spectacular super-weapons to carry out your nefarious master...
minimum_requirements: Supported OS: Microsoft Windows XP / Vista                    Processor: Pentium® III 800MHz processor                    Memory: 128MB RAM                    Graphics: GeForce2 16Mb or equivalent                     Hard Drive: 1.4 GB of free hard drive space                    Sound Card: Windows compatible sound cardDirectX9®: DirectX 9.0c

reviews.review_text: One of my favorite games of all time. Where other games similar to Dungeon Keeper failed, Evil Genius succeeded in so many ways while also creating a world that was unique in itself. The goal of the game is to build an evil secret base on a deserted island and further your plans of world domination. Be careful, however, for the forces of good will do everything in their power to stop you from fulfilling those dreams. You control everything from a birds-eye view where you build rooms and objects via 'blueprints' which Minions then proceed to purchase and place for you. The game overall is very smooth and challenging. After all these years, I still haven't managed to beat the game and I bought it when it first came out! All in all, I love this game and I highly recommend it to anyone who wants to rule the world and throw foolish special agents into giant mixer bowls.

Let me say one thing first. I have played and loved Dungeon Keeper 1,2 as well as Evil Genius. Saying Evil Genius is a clone of Dungeon Keeper is to me like saying Chess(EG) is a clone of checkers(DK). There are similarities but one is a lot deeper and harder to master than the other. There is nothing before or since like Evil Genius. There have been attempts to do something like Dungeon Keeper with mixed results. No one has to my knowledge has even tried with Evil Genius. It is also the only game I know where so many people(like me) are crying for a sequel. The game does have some flaws involving minion, space and gold management. The learning curve is very steep at some points and it is not always intuitive how you do some simple things like interrogate a prisoner. Even with the bugfix patch it can be a little unstable. For the first time through, expect that you will have to go to the glossery and the internet for help and that you should save often. Even on easy mode, Marimba Mamba (the weakest superagent) is most likely going to wipeout many of your high level minions, steal some of your ill gotten goodies and blow up your power stations while you are checking on an act of infamy. On the plus side there is a lot of humor and some replayability. The graphics are dated but it still looks good. It is worth buying this game, even at its non-sale price.

Easily one of the best simulators where you play the bad guys on the market.  Has lots of content, from resource management and minion management to traps and worldwide domination. It does not fall short in any catagory other than story, as there is not much of one, so there is much room for roleplay in this game. Small price tag adds even more to the value, and it's a great game to play to kill time, be it in one sitting or in short bursts. Has a charming humor to it, and the lack of any real dismemberment and bloody carnage further adds this charm to it. The game can be very difficult and very frustrating, especially the last half of the game, but it only adds to the flavour of the game.  10/10, would lock Russians in a giant venus flytrap filled room again.

A seriously underrated classic. Anybody who was twitching anxiously back in 2005 for Dungeon Keeper III picked up this game like a heroin addict picking up used syringes for their fix. Much to our surprise, we got an entertaining, visually interesting, and mentally tantalizing base-building strategy game with far more depth than you might assume going into it - and far more challenge, too.  The premise is pretty simple: you're an evil genius just starting out on his road to world domination - but first you need a base of operations complete with your evil lab, your own private prison, your vault to store ill-gotten goods and your gold, your private sanctum for meeting with the world's biggest and baddest, and of course traps and security measures galore to keep out pesky special agents. What better location than a tropical volcanic island? The user interface and controls are easy to master and the tutorial takes about five to ten minutes to complete. But once you do that, it's on to figuring out how your minions work and function as they all have their own AI and need certain things to function at maximum capacity. Be prepared to make back-up saves and potentially start all over after having realized your entire lay-out for the base is inefficient and wrong. There's no shame in checking out a few guides for this one. Of course if you're an AbsoluteMadman(TM) then feel free to blow up the whole thing and start again - yes, you can do that.  The game has tons of interesting features and you'll find yourself attached to all the characters, from your own avatar (this game begs for customizable avatars and not presets), your personal elite henchmen, and all your various science, military, and social minions. The game does a pretty great job explaining its features so I won't linger on that too long, and it keeps a steady stream of new toys for you to play with and make you engaged.  A pretty great way to chew up an afternoon or seven. I highly reccommend it.

But Evil Genius completely crushed this golden oppurtunity with terrible AI, and tedious grinding.  One of the HUGEST problems with Evil Genius is the way your 'Minions' work. In a game like this, you're supposed to feel like a badass, as you epicly fight through enemy soldiers with your loyal army of minions. But in Evil Genius, you don't feel like a badass, you feel like a victim. As soldiers wave through corpses of your minions while your remaining soldiers constantly desert you every 5 ♥♥♥♥ing minutes.  The only way to keep up your minions 'loyalty' is by interrogating enemy investigators/soldiers you captured. Which is extremely hard to do depending on the way you play. Minions drain on loyalty completely every 3 minutes, and depending on your heat trespassers barely ever show up.  While their not busy constantly deserting, their busy going insane, getting stuck in a corner on a big piece of nothing as they suck up minion space.  So then your last saving grace is a henchman, which you only get about 3 of in the time you play.  Evil genius can be fun in the first couple hours, but it gets REALLY frustrating, REALLY fast.

Evil Genius is what happens when Dungeon Keeper and James Bond villains have a child together. You play, as the game's title says, an evil genius, bent on destroying the forces of good and conquering the whole world. You start off on a small island paradise, with only a handful of minions, 250,000 dollars, and a single henchmen. From there, your task is to build a complex base of operations into the mountainside, complete with traps, training facilities, and more, while at the same time plundering riches and fighting off the constant intrusions from the forces of justice. Evil Genius manages to bring out the worst in all of us, and you'll be surprised to find yourself stalking the despised well-doers as they land on your little shred of land, eager to find out how they will meet your demise. And with ways ranging from bazooka-wielding Russians, to a complex set of bee-related traps, you'll find dozens of ways to amuse yourself with their death.

I missed this game when it first released but had always wanted to give it a go as I heard it was similar to Dungeon Keeper, a much loved game from my early PC gaming days. After seeing it had launched on Steam for a modest price I snagged a copy and am pleasantly surprised by how in depth this hidden gem is, in some ways I actually prefer it to Dungeon Keeper.   The interesting thing about this villainous base builder is that rather than building small lairs and moving from level to level, you only have two islands to build on, one that you access from the start and another that unlocks halfway through. This allows you to expand your HQ over time and it's a rewarding experience to finally see your underground criminal empire begin to flourish. You also have access to a world map screen that allows you to influence the world outside of your base by sending your henchmen to commit crimes or perform espionage in various countries which brings in gold, specialist units and ups your notoriety. But beware, the more influential you become, the more secret agents the governments of the world will send to your island to unravel your insidious schemes. It should be noted that the game's theme is heavily influenced by 60s spy serials and it carries this off with a comedic tone reminiscent of the Austin Powers movies, which I rather enjoyed.  If you're a fan of Dungeon Keeper or looking to get into to the whole base building, overlord style strategy genre, I highly recommend this game. It's a great time sink and it's easy to lose a few hours twiddling your evil moustache and plotting world domination. Just be sure to watch out for that pesky super agent John Steele.

Many of the issues I believe would be worked out in a sequel, though rumours have been circulating for years whether this will happen. Personally I would love to play a sequel that captures the humourous spirit of the original with some of the edges smoothed off.

This game mixes base building perfectly with solid retrospective humour. Those of you familiar with old James Bond movies, with feel right at home with this games comedic foundations. The game will have you developing traps that open the floor to a deadly pit of saws one minute and then have you interrogating a prisioner with Micheal Jackson choreography the next.   The game oozes with charm. Not only that, but the game offers a solid strategic challenge as well. You will find yourself having to keep track of both your base activies and your world domition tactics on the world map (Think total war, but with everything happening at once). This sense of micro-management will never leave you bored, or unatentive. The game always presents a obstacle for you to overcome, rather that be enemy agents trying to inflitrate your base, a power failure leaving your base vunerable or trying to keep pesky tourists from wondering into your evil lair the game consistently presents you with challenges, some difficult some not, and never at any point leaves you with nothing to do.   Overall, this game is ranked in my Steam favourites. The game is genuinly funny and light hearted. It presents challenge with its gameplay, has a addictive formula to boot and is a hit for those who are fans of games like Dungeon(s) Keeper, Tropico and the like.

Such a great old game. Absolutely delightful to play through again. Drags a little as you must wait for minions to be replaced or to repair your base but all the great animations and little details to make your evil base come alive is outstanding to watch. The game draws a great line between the funny and the evil of being someone ambitious enough to rule the world. The desciptions and radio messages of 'Acts of Infamy' are great. Interrogating 'forces of justice' and 'superagents' is entertaining. Missing a piece of loot because of moving to your second evil liar or missing an important piece of labortaory equipment brings down the game. However, these small detriments to the game do not take away from the overall enjoyment.   I would love to see this game get a little old school love like some other titles. The addition of achievements (which there could be a number of great fun ones i.e. trap combinations) would add a more longevity to this aging title.  Too much to hope that we will ever see a Evil Genius 2? Similar to Dungeon Keep 1 and 2, we will see poor clones or attempts. This one is a classic and a must play especially for those with an inner evil heart inside!  Absolutely recommended.  -Chaos

There are, of course, more games where you play an evil overlord (hello, Overlord!). There are also, of course, more games that focus on building an underground lair as an evil overlord (hello, Dungeon Keeper!). But there is, so far, only one Evil Genius. A must-play for all would-be criminal masterminds seeking world domination.   Amazingly, Evil Genius still looks fresh 12 years after its first release - mainly due to its cartoon-like graphics and wacky sense of humour. It's not a particularly hard game to learn; it's not even particularly hard to master as long as you remember to pace yourself a little. Perhaps most importantly, it's a game where actually winning is only part of the challenge. After all, why would you try to rush towards victory when there's so many deliciously vicious ways of dealing with your opponents (and the occasional disloyal minion) to think of? And remember, if things do take a turn for the worse, it's not your fault - it's just that you're surrounded by incompetent fools!  Unfortunately, a minor expansion pack (the World Somination Kit), including an extra henchman, is not included in the Steam release - but it is still available online, so don't forget to grab that one, too.
